questions.text: Which of the following is the manifestation of increased estrogen levels in Cirrhosis?
Which of the following is not typically associated with developing fatty liver disease?
Which of the following is typically observed in liver biopsy findings of acute hepatitis A infection?
questions.explanation:
Acute Hepatitis

Chronic Hepatitis
  • Ballooning degeneration
  • Councilman bodies
  • Spotty necrosis
  • Dropout necrosis and Kupffer cell hyperplasia
  • Absent or mild portal inflammation
  • Interface hepatitis
  • Ground glass hepatocytes
  • Bridging necrosis
  • Lymphoplasmacytic infiltration
  • Extensive portal inflammation

questions.text: What is the most likely autoantibody detected in Type I autoimmune hepatitis (AIH)?
questions.explanation:
Features

Type I AIH

Type II AIH

More common in
  • Young female
  • Children

Auto-antibodies
  • Anti SMA (Anti smooth muscle antibody) (Option B)
  • ANA (Anti-nuclear antibody)
  • Anti-soluble liver antigen
  • Anti LKM- 1 (Hepatitis C) (Option A)
  • Anti–liver cytosol-1 (ACL-1) (Option C)
  • Anti LKM- 3 (Hepatitis D)

Histopathology
  • Interface hepatitis with a plasma cell-rich infiltrate.
  • Foci of necrosis, ballooning degeneration of hepatocytes, and regenerative changes such as hepatocyte rosette formation.

questions.text: A 45-year-old male with diabetes mellitus presents with fatigue and abdominal discomfort. He denies any history of alcohol consumption. Laboratory tests show elevated serum AST and ALT levels. Imaging reveals hepatic steatosis. Which of the following is consistent with the patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Features

NASH

(Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis)

Alcoholic steatohepatitis

Risk factors

Obesity 

Diabetes mellitus (Option C)

Dyslipidemia (Option D ruled out)

Alcohol intake

AST/ALT Ratio

AST/ALT < 1 (Option A and B ruled out)

AST/ALT > 2

GGT levels

Normal

Increased

questions.text: Which of the following changes is reversible with alcohol abstinence?
Which of the following conditions is not typically associated with Mallory-Denk bodies?

A 51-year-old male with a history of chronic alcohol use presents with fatigue, abdominal discomfort, and unintentional weight loss. A biopsy of the liver was done. Which of the following histopathological features is characteristic of the condition depicted in the biopsy image?

A 60-year-old male presents with abdominal distension and jaundice. Examination reveals hepatosplenomegaly. Lab tests show elevated liver enzymes and decreased albumin levels. Imaging shows nodules <3mm throughout the liver. Which of the following conditions can present with these findings?
questions.explanation:
Causes of micronodular cirrhosis
(Granule size <3mm)

Causes of macronodular cirrhosis
(Granule size >3mm)
  1. Early stage of Alcoholic Liver Disease (ALD)
  2. Indian Childhood Cirrhosis (ICC)
  3. Primary Biliary Cirrhosis (PBC)
  4. Hemochromatosis (Option C)
  5. Hepatic venous outflow obstruction (Budd-Chiari syndrome)
  1. Late stage of alcoholic liver disease (ALD)
  2. Viral hepatitis (Option A)
  3. Wilson disease (Option D)
  4. Drug-induced hepatitis (Option B)
  5. Alpha-1 antitrypsin deficiency

questions.text: Which cells are primarily involved in the fibrosis in liver cirrhosis?
Which of the following stains would be most useful for highlighting collagen deposition in the fibrotic areas of the liver?
Which type of collagen is predominantly involved in the fibrotic process of cirrhosis?
questions.correct_answer: A. Collagen Type I and III

questions.text: A 45-year-old male presents with fatigue, pruritus, and jaundice. He has a history of ulcerative colitis. Laboratory tests reveal elevated liver enzymes and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia. MRCP and Histopathological findings from liver biopsy are given below. Which condition is most likely responsible for these findings?
questions.explanation:
Primary sclerosing cholangitis (PSC)
 

Primary biliary cholangitis or
Primary biliary cirrhosis (PBC)
(Option B)

Seen in 30 years old; M>F

Seen in >50 years old; F>M

p-ANCA positive

p-ANCA is also seen in

  • Microscopic polyangitis
  • Churg Strauss syndrome
  • Ulcerative colitis
  • Primary sclerosing cholangitis
  • Goodpasture syndrome
  • Pauci-immune glomerulonephritis
  • Rheumatoid arthritis

AMA(Anti-mitochondrial antibody) and ANA(anti-nuclear antibody) positive

Associated with ulcerative colitis, HLA-B8

Associated with Sjogren syndrome, scleroderma

Intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts are affected

Intrahepatic bile ducts affected

HPE: Concentric periductal fibrosis (Onion skin fibrosis)

  

Radiology: Pruning of small bile ducts; Strictures and beading of large bile ducts.

 

Radiology: Normal

questions.text: A 35-year-old male presents with chronic jaundice and mild abdominal discomfort. Examination revealed hepatomegaly. Lab tests indicate elevated levels of direct bilirubin. Upon liver biopsy, a pigmented liver is observed. What is the most likely underlying mechanism for these clinical and pathological findings?
questions.explanation:
Type of hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia 

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1

Complete deficiency of UGT. (Option A)

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2

Partial deficiency of UGT.

Gilbert syndrome

Very mild deficiency of UGT.

Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein. (Option C)

 

Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite)

Rotor syndrome

Defect in ATPs (decreased biliary excretion)

 

Non-pigmented liver

questions.text: A 2-week-old infant presents with persistent jaundice since birth and markedly elevated unconjugated bilirubin levels (>20 mg/dL) despite exposure to sunlight. Genetic testing confirms homozygosity for a specific mutation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Syndromes of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Severity of Unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 1 (Option A)

Complete deficiency of UGT

Severe

Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2 (Option B)

Partial deficiency of UGT

Mild to moderate

Gilbert syndrome (Option C)

Very mild deficiency of UGT

Mild, asymptomatic

Syndromes of Conjugated hyperbilirubinemia

Disorder

Defect

Gross Feature of liver

Dubin Johnson syndrome

Defect in canalicular MRP2 protein.

Pigmented liver (due to epinephrine metabolite)

Rotor syndrome (Option D)

Defect in ATPs (decreased biliary excretion)

Non pigmented liver

questions.text: Which change can be seen in a structure that connects hepatocytes with cholangiocytes?
Which zone of the liver lobule is primarily affected by toxins and drug metabolism?
questions.explanation:
Zone

Location

Hepatocyte characteristics

Sensitivity to Injury

Zone 1
(periportal zone)
(Option A)

Around the portal tracts

High oxygenation, reduced metabolic activity,
Rich blood supply

 Least susceptibile to toxin-mediated and ischemic injury

Zone 2
(mid zonal zone)
(Option B)

Between zone 1 and zone 3

Intermediate oxygenation, metabolic activity and blood supply

Moderate susceptibility to toxin-mediated and ischemic injury

Zone 3 (perivenous zone/ pericentral zone)
(Option C)

Around the central vein

Low oxygenation,
active metabolism,
Poor blood supply

Susceptible to drugs/toxin-mediated damage and  ischemic injury during hypoperfusion of the liver

questions.text: Which of the following cytokines is not typically involved in promoting fibrogenesis and hepatic stellate cell activation in chronic liver diseases?
questions.explanation:
Factors

Role in hepatic pathology

Interleukin 10 (Option C)
  • Antiinflammatory
  • Inhibits hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Reduces fibrogenesis by counteracting pro-inflammatory cytokines

Interleukin 6 (Option A)
  • Pro-inflammatory
  • Stimulates hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Promotes fibrogenesis and inflammation in chronic liver diseases
  • Associated with hepatic regeneration

Platelet derived growth factor (PDGF) (Option B)
  • Stimulates hepatic stellar cell activation
  • Promotes proliferation and migration of HSC to site of injury
  • Contributes to fibrogenesis

Transforming growth factor - β (TGF-β) (Option D)
  • Promotes profibrotic cytokines in liver diseases
  • Stimulates HSC activation and transformation into myofibroblast
  • Enhances Extracellular Matrix production and inhibits ECM degradation
